titleStmt.title: Tracer diffusion of potassium, rubidium, and cesium in a supercooled jadeite melt

analytic.title: Tracer diffusion of potassium, rubidium, and cesium in a supercooled jadeite melt

biblStruct.note: Received August 23, 1996; accepted in revised form April 4, 1997

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: Tracer diffusion coefficients of K, Rb, and Cs were determined in a supercooled jadeite melt using the thin source technique. Experiments were performed at temperatures between 800 and 1020°C at 1 bar pressure. Run times ranged from 5 min to 26 days. Diffusion profiles were measured using the electron microprobe and diffusion coefficients were found to be independent of the amount of tracer initially deposited on the sample surface. Variation of the run times yielded identical diffusivities within experimental error. The dependence of the diffusivity D with temperature T can be described with an Arrhenian equation D = D,exp( -EJRT).
A least squares fit yields DK = 5.7. 10-6exp( -127/RT), DRb = 5.9. 10-6exp(-163/RT),

and DCs = 2.0. 10-4exp( -243/RT), with DO in m2/s and E, in kJ1 mol. The diffusivity decreases with increasing ionic radius while the activation energy increases. Along the composition join silica-jadeite, similar diffusivities are exhibited by albite and jadeite compositions, whereas diffusivity in silica appears to be up to 2 orders of magnitude lower. The activation energies of K and Rb reveal a minimum at albite composition and a maximum for Cs, whereas the activation energy of Na decreases continously with increasing AIlSi ratio. When compared with neutral species, alkalies with the same radius exhibit higher activation energies.

div.head: INTRODUCTION
div.p: Kinetic information is needed to understand magmatic processes like crystal growth and dissolution from a silicate melt or the influence of diffusion on trace element partitioning (e.g., Albarbde and Bottinga, 1972;Magaritz and Hofmann, 1978). Fundamental for such processes is the understanding of the structure and dynamics of silicate melts. Since diffusion is envisaged in general as an exchange process involving available empty space (e.g., for network modifying cations) in the melt structure, systematic investigations of diffusion processes as a function of composition, temperature, and pressure, involving differently charged and sized species give insight into the structure and dynamics of silicate melts. Such systematic studies are necessary to develop quantitative models of diffusion mechanisms in silicate melts and glasses.

The diffusion measurements presented in this paper were performed on a jadeite (Jd) composition with some additional measurements on albite (Ab). They extend previous investigations of the diffusivity of alkalies along the join Si02-NaAlSi206. In vitreous silica (Qz) and albite the diffusivities of Li, Na, K, Rb, and Cs have already been investigated by both tracer diffusion and electrical conductivity measurements (Silica: Doremus;1969, Frischat, 1970;;Zhabrevet al., 1976;Rothman et al., 1982;Albite: Carron, 1969;Jambon and Carron, 1976;Jambon and Semet, 1978;Fritzsche, 1990;Fuchser, 1996). Fritzsche (1990) and Fuchser ( 1996) also performed electrical conductivity measurements in a jadeite composition. Additionally, data are available for the diffusivity of Na in intermediate compositions ( QzSOAb5" : Carron, 1969;Ab5 JdsO: Fritzsche, 1990;Fuchser, 1996) from electrical conductivity studies and tracer diffusion experiments of Na in Abs Jd50 (Williams and Heckman, 1964). Moreover, diffusivities of noble gases are available allowing a comparison between different sized single charged and neutral species (Silica: Swets et al., 1961;Frank et al., 1961;Shelby, 1971Shelby, , 1972;;Perkins and Begeal, 1971;Nakayama and Shackelford, 1990;Wortman and Shackelford, 1990;Carroll and Stolper, 1991;Carroll et al., 1993;Roselieb et al., 1995;Albite: Carroll, 1991;Carroll et al., 1993;Roselieb et al., 1992Roselieb et al., , 1995)). Diffusivities of Ar, Kr, and Xe in a supercooled jadeite melt have been investigated by Roselieb et al. ( 1995). Further available are permeation measurements of He in glasses of albite and jadeite composition (Shelby and Eagan, 1976).

According to the X-ray diffraction studies of Konnert and Karle (1973) and Taylor and Brown ( 1979), glasses and supercooled melts along the join Si02-NaAlSi206 can be described as having a stuffed tridymite-like structure. Herein, with increasing substitution of Si by (Al + Na), half of the available interstices in albite and two-thirds in jadeite are filled by Na. Consequently, the structure becomes increasingly stuffed, and the number of available empty sites are progressively reduced. This qualitative model is in agreement with noble gas solubility measurements: with increasing substitution of Si by (Na + Al) the solubility of noble gases decreases (Roselieb et al., 1992;Roselieb, 1992). Therefore, investigations of the mobility of various alkali cations as well as uncharged particles in the anionic structure promise further insight into the structure of silicate melts and glasses.

The experiments on jadeite and albite composition are performed in a temperature range where structural relaxation times measured by dynamic light scattering (e.g., at 800°C: 0.5 s and 36 s for albite (Siewert and Rosenhauer, 1997) and jadeite (Siewert and Rosenhauer, 1994), respectively) are much shorter than our run durations (at least 1800 s at

div.head: 800°C
div.p: ). Therefore, the tracer diffusion experiments were performed on a relaxed melt, and we refer to it as a supercooled melt. It is noteworthy that the measurements of Siewert and Rosenhauer ( 1994) on jadeite composition are performed on the same batch of jadeite sample as used for the tracer diffusion measurements presented in this paper.

div.head: Starting Material and Experimental Procedure
div.p: The jadeite glass was prepared by Schott-Glaswerke, Mainz, Germany. It is from the same batch as the samples previously used for the electrical conductivity measurements of Na (Fritzsche, 1990;Fuchser, 1996), noble gas solubility studies (Roselieb, 1992). light scattering investigations (Siewert and Rosenhauer, 1994) and noble gas diffusion experiments (Roselieb et al., 1995). Cylinders of 3.6 mm height and 2.6 mm diameter or cubes of 2 mm edge length were prepared from the glass starting material. Some runs were performed on albite glass, prepared from oxides by D. Dingwell (Bayreuth ).
From the albite batch cuboids with an edge length of 2 mm and height of 3 mm were cut. Chemical analysis of the two starting glasses are given in Table I.
A chloride solution was deposited on a polished surface of the cylinder, cube, or cuboid. To produce a thin source of the tracer the sample was shortly preannealed.

Typical preannealing was conducted between 450 and 600°C for 2-16 min (K), 670 and 850°C for 2-8 min (Rb), and 670 and 1060°C for 2 min to 90 h (Cs). The variation of the preannealing temperatures and times allows the preparation of samples with varying amounts of the tracer. After that the sample is washed in distilled water to remove the salt from the polished surface.
For the diffusion experiment, the sample is mounted in a I bar furnace in air. Run temperatures ranged from 800 to 1020°C and were measured with a Pt94Rhb-Pt70RhJ0 thermocouple.

The temperature is calibrated against the melting point of Au and is believed to be accurate to within 25°C. Run temperatures are reached within 90 s to 5 min, depending on run temperature. Run times varied from 5 min to 26 days. The inspection of the run products under the binocular revealed no evidence for recrystallization. Some samples were slightly rounded which has no significant influence on the diffusion coefficients, because these diffusion coefficients agree within error with results from other samples.

After the diffusion experiment the samples were sectioned in half perpendicular to the starting interface and polished. The microprobe analysis was done with a CAMECA SX 50 using the K,-line of K and the L,-lines of Rb and Cs. Operation conditions were 15 kV, 40 nA, and count rates of IO-20 s (K) and 20-35 s (Rb, Cs). Typical beam diameter was between 10 and 20 pm. Potassium, rubidium, and cesium were found to be stable under the analytical conditions, checked by repeated measurements on the same point (compare below). The concentration of the tracer was measured as a function of the distance from the sample edge. All profiles were measured fully automatically.
Typical diffusion profiles of K, Rb, and Cs are presented in Fig. 1.
The measured profiles were fitted with the corresponding solution of a thin source on top of a semi-infinite cylinder (Crank, 1975):
(1) 2 and3 for jadeite and albite composition. respectively.

Solving the exponential Eqn. I without linearizing yields the same results within error. However, the nonlinearized solution is more sensitive for profiles of poorer quality. Since for some of the Cs profiles in albite only a few data points are collected, especially those with shallow penetration and low concentrations of the tracer, we employed a nonlinearized fit to the Cs profiles in albite. The error of the tit of an individual profile is usually 5 i-O.05 log-units ( I ir ). The errors given in Tables 2 and3 experiment. Since these samples yield the same results as samples with regular near-surface profiles, we conclude that this has no significant influence on the diffusion coefficients.

div.head: Dependence of the Diffusion Coefficient on the Initial Deposit of the Tracer
div.p: Since we introduced a trace element with a concentration above those initially present in the jadeite composition, chemical gradients are responsible for the diffusion process. Typical near-surface concentrations ranged from -400 to 8000 ppm, and we assume that the introduced concentrations of the tracer are too small to produce any other significant concentration gradients (i.e., dilute system). Therefore, we believe that the obtained diffusion coefficients are close to self diffusion and do not depend on the concentration of the tracer within error. However, as discussed quantitatively by Wei and Wuensch ( 1976), tracer diffusion coefficients depend exponentially on concentration. This is important in the early stage of the diffusion experiment, where the tracer concentration is still enriched and can falsify the calculated diffusion coefficients from profiles with high tracer concentrations and shallow penetration. To check the above assumption, we varied the amount of the initially deposited tracer by varying the pre-anneal conditions. This approach Do (m'/s) E, (kJ/mol) Jadeite error. However, with substitution of (Na + Al) for Si the diffusivity increases, and this effect is more pronounced with increasing size of the cation. Whereas Na is similar in all three compositions, Cs diffusivity is more than 2 orders of magnitude lower in silica than in the aluminosilicates. glassy into the supercooled melt state, which can be well described by a single straight line in an Arrhenian plot with no significant changes near T, (e.g., for albite and orthoclase, Jambon and Carron, 1976;or for obsidian, Jambon, 1982). However, Behrens ( 1992) observed different behaviour of the self diffusion of Na in glasses and supercooled melts of plagioclase composition, indicating higher activation energies in the supercooled melt. Roselieb et al. ( 1995) proposed that structural relaxation could possibly enhance the diffusivity of noble gases in supercooled melts of the system SiOz-NaAlSi,O,.

According to electrical conductivity measurements of Fritzsche ( 1990) and Fuchser ( 1996), activation energies above the glass transition temperature are roughly 10% higher than in the glassy state for various compositions (e.g., along the join SiO*-NaAlSi04, orthoclase). Therefore. differences in the structural state should not invalidate the following discussion as this effect is probably within the experimental error.

div.head: Comparison of the Diffusivity in the System SiOz-NaA1Si206
div.p: According to Fig. 3, the diffusivity of K, Rb, and Cs in a supercooled jadeite melt decreases with increasing cation size. This same feature is observed in isostructural compositions in the system Si02-NaAlSi20h (e.g., Rothman et al., 1982;Jambon and Carron, 1976; for a data compilation see Fig. 4a) as well as for vitreous orthoclase (Jambon and Carron, 1976) or natural melts, e.g., obsidian and basalt (see Hofmann ( 1980) for a data compilation).
Figure 4 compares the available data for alkalies in the system SiO*-NaAlSi20h.

The available data from the literature for the diffusivities of Na (e.g., Frischat, 1970) and Rb (Rothman et al., 1982) in vitreous silica exhibit a significant spread. For clarity in the presentation in Fig. 4a, we show only the data from Frischat ( 1970) for the high temperature range from 600 to 1000°C for Na (mean value for various silica glasses, Table 3, Frischat, 1970) and the mean value from Rothman et al. (1982) for Rb. Figure 4a shows an Arrhenian diagram including our results for supercooled albite melt (Table 3) indicated by the symbols. Figure 4b compares the diffusivities at constant temperature of 900°C. In general, diffusivities of the alkali ions in albite and jadeite are very similar and indistinguishable within experimental
We can compare now the activation energy of diffusion for particles having different charge and size in the system silica-jadeite.

Since a nearly complete dataset is available only for alkalies and noble gases, the following discussion is limited to single charged and neutral species. For He, only an activation energy for permeation in albite and jadeite glass is available (Shelby and Eagan. 1976), and this could differ from that for diffusion depending on the temperature dependence of He solubility in the glasses. Figure 5 presents the available activation energies as a function of particle radius in the system silica-jadeite.

The activation energy 3): K (cross), Rb (dots), and Cs (open circles). Data sources: silica: Na (Frischat, 1970), K, Rb, Cs (Rothman et al., 1982); albite: Na, K, Rb, Cs (Jambon and Carron, 1976); jadeite: Na (Fuchser, 1996). K, Rb, Cs (this study, Table 4). (b) Diffusivities at 900°C as function of the AI/(Al + Si) ratio. Dashed line indicates trend of the data. Data sources: see Fig. 4 (a); additional data for Na: albite: Carron ( 1969): Fuchser (1996); Qz5&bs0: Carron ( 1969); Ab5rJd50: Williams and Heckman (1964). Fuchser (1996) and for Cs: albite: this study (Table 4).
increases with increasing size of the diffusing species for both charged and uncharged particles.
With increasing charge the activation energy increases. A striking feature in Fig. 5 is that Na exhibits the lowest activation energy of the alkalies in silica and albite composition.

Unfortunately, no Li data are yet available for jadeite composition. Similar behaviour is observed for the alkalies in obsidian (Jambon and Semet, 1978). For vitreous orthoclase, however, the lowest activation energy of the alkalies is observed for K (Jambon and Semet, 1978). This behaviour possibly indicates that Na best fits into available holes in the anionic melt structure of silica and albite, whereas in the more loosely packed orthoclase, K has the minimum activation energy. Further evidence stems from electrical conductivity measurements: Fuchser ( 1996) determined Na and K diffusion values from impedance measurements in vitreous albite, an albite-jadeite mixture, and orthoclase similar to tracer diffusivities of Na and K measured by Jambon and Carron ( 1976) and Williams and Heckman ( 1964). This supports the view that the anionic network remains unchanged during a jump of an alkali ion, and the only contribution to the electrical conductivity stems from the mobility of the alkalies.

Solubility studies of noble gases in supercooled melts along the join silica-jadeite (Roselieb et al., 1992;Roselieb, 1992) yield decreasing solubilities with increasing introduction of Na from silica to jadeite. This is interpreted to mean that noble gases occupy similar voids and holes in the melt structure as Na. On the basis of the solubility measurements of noble gases and the observed uniform increase of the activation energies of alkalies and noble gases with increasing radius (Fig. 5 ), one could assume that both neutral and charged particles diffuse through similar voids in the vitreous structure. This implies that the environment of the diffusing species is similar. Therefore, the only difference during a diffusive jump results from the charge and size of the diffusing particle. According to Jambon ( 1982)) activation energy during a diffusive jump may comprise a number of contributions: energy of defect formation, shear energy upon jumping, and electrostatic contribution for charged cations. The shear energy needed to dilate the network upon jumping increases with increasing size of the diffusiving species and emerges quite clearly from the activation energy to size relationship of all compositions investigated (Fig. 5). For the composition investigated, the low activation energies compared to that for oxygen diffusion (Shimizu and Kushiro, 1984) or viscous flow (Riebling, 1966;Taylor and Rindone, 1970;Stein and Spera, 1993) or viscoelastic relaxation (Siewert and Rosenhauer, 1994)) show that Si-0 bonds are not broken during a jump, but that elastic repulsion of oxygen can be a significant contribution, especially for large cations (or atoms). The electrostatic contribution is clearly visible when noble gas and alkali activation energies are compared (Fig. 5). The behaviour of Li possibly results from the greater electrostatic contribution of the small cation in addition to a minimal shear energy upon jumping. This effect would be even more pronounced for multiply charged catios (see e.g., Jambon, 1982) which on the average are smaller but have higher activation energies than alkalies.

Before we evaluate the influence of the substitution of (Na + Al) for Si on the activation energy along the silica-jadeite join, two general points have to be discussed. First, we assume the chemical compositions of the investigated glasses and melts for all compositions to be representative, i.e., stoichiometric.
Second, the significance of the observed trend has to be considered with respect to the error of the measurements.

Figure 6 summarizes the mean values of the activation energies of the alkalies and noble gases (excluding Li and Ne where no data for jadeite compositions are available) from various measurements of different authors and techniques. Also given are the la error bars, which are usually within the symbol size or only slightly larger, demonstrating that the variation in the available data is significant. Among the largest errors are those of Na and Rb in silica, which derive from the spread of the available literature data (see above). The errors of the activation energies for Xe are very liberal estimates from only one measurement (see Roselieb et al., 1995). The large error bar for He in albite results from the large difference between the data of Shelby and Eagan ( 1976) and Roselieb et al. ( 1992) with 32 and 67 kJ/mol, respectively.

However, the comparison of the trend along the join silica-jadeite from Fig. 5 may indicate that the activation energies for He and Ne from Roselieb et al. ( 1992) are too high. Therefore, the following discussion needs to be supported by additional measurements in order to further constrain the available data, as well as to study the influence of stoichiometry on the activation energies and to extend the measurements to intermediate samples. However, two distinct trends can be observed for the noble gases and alkalies from Fig. 6. The noble gases show nearly identical behaviour as a function of composition. The activation energy for He, Ar, Kr, and Xe increases with increasing substitution of (Na + Al) for Si, even if the activation energies in albite and jadeite agree within experimental error. In the case of alkalies, the activation energy of Na decreases continously from silica to jadeite (Fig. 6). Although the activation energies of Na in the aluminosilicate compositions agree within the error of the measurements, this trend is further supported for intermediate compositions of Qz5,,Ab5,, (Carron, 1969) and Ab5 JdsO (Williams and Heckman, 1964;Fritzsche, 1990;Fuchser, 1996). In contrast to Na, a minimum in the activation energy is found for K and Rb at albite composition, which is clearly evident on the basis of the lcr error for K but is less marked for Rb because of the large error bars for Rb in silica (see above). The activation energy of Cs behaves differently from the other alkalies and clearly increases from silica to albite, possibly exhibiting a maximum in the activation energy for albite composition. This maximum is clearly present if only the data of Jambon and Carron ( 1976) are considered. When we include the activation energy from our measurements from this study, derived from only two runs, this maximum is further supported (on the basis of a lg error level) if we use the exponential function (see above). It should be mentioned that the calculation of the diffusion coefficients of Cs from the linearized profiles yields a slightly lower activation energy, and consequently a lower mean value for Cs in albite, but which is still high in comparison to jadeite, although the activation energies then agree within lg error level. However, the dependence of the activation energy of Cs as a function of substitution of (Na + Al) for Si is significantly different from those of the other alkalies.

With the substitution of (Na + Al) for Si the anionic network changes from neutral to negative charge so that alkalies (e.g., Na) are required for charge balancing. As the other alkalies can contribute to charge balancing as well, the mobilities of cations could be enhanced in the negatively charged network. This would result in lower activation energies of cations (Na, K, and Rb) in albite compared to silica. With a further increase in the substitution of (Na + Al) for Si from albite towards jadeite, increasing structural disorder is observed by radial distribution analysis (Taylor and Brown, 1979), and the presence of four-and six-membered rings by Raman spectroscopy (Seifert et al., 1982). In agree- ment with this observation are the observed decreasing noble gas solubilities (Roselieb et al., 1992;Roselieb, 1992). Therefore, with increasing introduction of (Na + Al) available voids and ring sizes are reduced, and it is more difficult for a large particle such as K or Rb to diffuse through the network, whereas the activation energy of Na decreases further with increasing AI/S1 ratio. The different behaviour of Cs (possibly indicating a maximum at albite composition) may indicate that greater ring sizes are much more sensitive to the introduction of Na and Al than smaller ones. In comparison to alkalies, noble gases are sensitive only to decreasing ring sizes and exhibit increasing activation energies with increasing Al/Si ratio.

div.head: CONCLUSIONS
div.p: Tracer diffusion profiles of K, Rb, and Cs were measured using an electron microprobe, and the estimated diffusion coefficients are close to self diffusion coefficients. With increasing size of the alkali ion the diffusivity decreases, and the activation energy increases. A comparison with available data in the system silica-jadeite reveals nearly identical diffusivities in albite and jadeite composition, whereas in silica alkali diffusivities are considerably lower by up to 2 orders of magnitude. Plotting the activation energies vs. the ionic radius exhibit a minimum for Na in silica and albite composition. The substitution of Si by (Na + Al) results in a minimum in the activation energies of K and Rb for albite, whereas Cs shows a maximum. Activation energies of Na decreases progressively with increasing Al/Si ratio. The variation of the activation energies of alkalies and noble gases can be explained by the continous substitution of Si by (Na + Al), which causes changes in size, charge and the topology of the anionic network.

div.head: Acknowledgments-This
div.p: research is supported by the EC (HCMfellowship to K.R.) and during manuscript writing from the DFG (Ro 414/l 1), which is gratefully acknowledged. The support of M. Rosenhauer in the early stages of this project is greatly appreciated; he also provided the jadeite glass. D. Dingwell kindly fabricated the albite glass. E. Delairis, A. Hampe, and P. Meier are thanked for their technical assistance. The CAMPARIS team is thanked for their help during the electron microprobe work. S. Foley and R. Siewert improved the manuscript with helpful suggestions. D. R. Baker and Y. Liang provided helpful and constructive reviews.
